Story:
I sat on the couch next to my husband, our dinner plates still warm on the coffee table. He asked about my day, and I started to tell him about a tense moment at work, but my phone buzzed insistently. It was Mia, my closest friend, and her message popped up: “Hey, are we meeting at the café or your place? I’m confused.” I knew she’d been upset with me lately, and we’d agreed to talk things out tonight. She needed clarity, and I’d promised to be open and responsive.

But my husband was looking at me, waiting for me to finish my story, expecting the same openness we’d promised each other in our marriage. I could see he wanted my full attention, to feel like he mattered more than the distractions of the outside world. My phone buzzed again. I felt torn—if I ignored Mia, she might think I was avoiding her, making things worse. But if I picked up my phone now, my husband would feel sidelined, like he was second to my friends. My heart pounded as I stared at the screen, caught between two people who both needed me to be present, honest, and open—right now.
